we need the change to be compatable with our current theme system and use the same css for all page instead of the tendancy for the AI to create new for every new page. This change should be applied to all themes and instruction left for AI to see the prefered system and avoid changing the system without thought.

we need the change to be compatable with our current theme system and use the same css for all page instead of the tendancy for the AI to create new for every new page. Based on your request, here's a comprehensive prompt for normalizing container display across all themes: ## Container Standardization Prompt for Theme System ### CRITICAL INSTRUCTION: Container Theme Standardization **DO NOT CREATE NEW CSS FILES OR DUPLICATE CONTAINER STYLES** All pages MUST use the standardized Apiary container system. This is a project-wide standard that applies to ALL themes and ALL pages. ### Standard Container Structure Every page should use this exact container structure: ```html

Page Title

Label: Value
``` ### Required CSS Classes (Already Defined in apiary.css) **NEVER redefine these classes - they exist in `/Comserv/root/static/css/themes/apiary.css`:** - `.apiary-container` - Main page container with gradient background - `.apiary-header` - Page header with gradient and proper spacing - `.apiary-context` - Context information display - `.context-item` - Individual context elements - `.feature-card` - Standard card layout for content sections - `.feature-header` - Card headers with consistent styling - `.feature-content` - Card content areas - `.feature-actions` - Action button containers - `.btn`, `.btn-primary`, `.btn-secondary`, etc. - Standardized buttons ### Theme Integration Rules 1. **Link to apiary.css in ALL templates:** ```html ``` 2. **Use Apiary CSS Variables:** ```css :root { --apiary-primary: #f4a261; /* Honey orange */ --apiary-secondary: #e76f51; /* Warm red */ --apiary-accent: #2a9d8f; /* Teal green */ --apiary-dark: #264653; /* Dark green */ --apiary-light: #f1faee; /* Light cream */ --apiary-warning: #e9c46a; /* Golden yellow */ --apiary-success: #2a9d8f; /* Success green */ --apiary-danger: #e76f51; /* Danger red */ --apiary-info: #219ebc; /* Info blue */ } ``` 3. **Page-Specific CSS Rules:** - Only create page-specific CSS for functionality unique to that page - NEVER redefine container, header, or button styles - Use existing Apiary classes whenever possible - If you must add styles, extend existing classes, don't replace them ### Standard Content Patterns **For cards/sections:** ```html

Section Title

``` **For statistics/summary:** ```html
123 Label
``` ### Implementation Checklist When working on ANY page: 1. Does the page use `
`? 2. Does it have `
`? 3. Are you using existing `.feature-card` classes? 4. Are buttons using `.btn .btn-primary` etc.? 5. Are you linking to `apiary.css`? 6. Are you using Apiary CSS variables? 7. Are you creating new container/header/button styles? 8. Are you duplicating existing Apiary functionality? ### File Structure Rules - **apiary.css** - Contains ALL standard container, header, button, and layout styles - **[page].css** - Only contains page-specific functionality (tables, forms, unique features) - **Never create:** new-container.css, page-layout.css, custom-buttons.css ### Migration Instructions For existing pages that don't follow this standard: 1. Remove custom container/header CSS from page-specific files 2. Update HTML to use standard Apiary container structure 3. Replace custom buttons with `.btn` classes 4. Link to apiary.css 5. Test that page maintains functionality with standard styling ### Error Prevention **STOP and ask for clarification if:** - You're tempted to create new container styles - Existing Apiary classes don't seem to fit the use case - You're copying CSS from apiary.css to another file - You're modifying core Apiary container/header/button definitions **Remember:** The goal is consistency across all pages. Every page should look and feel like it belongs to the same application using the same design system. --- This standardization ensures: - Consistent user experience across all pages - Easier maintenance (one place to update styles) - Faster development (reuse existing components) - Better responsive design (already tested and working) - Theme compatibility (all themes can extend the same base)
